title: Martha Karua Arrives at Ugandan Court to Defend Detained Kizza Besigye, Aide
category: PoliticsNairobi CountyTanzaniaUgandaMartha KoomeProgressive commercial actorsLeanne GogginsPam Bales' ChildrenThank you wedding invitation messagesFunny Asian names
description: Senior counsel Martha Karua has joined the defence team for Ugandan opposition figure Kizza Besigye, just days after her recent deportation from Tanzania.

Introduction.text: Senior counsel Martha Karua was deported from Tanzania, where she had gone to observe the court hearing of opposition leader Tundu Lissu, who faces treason charges
Despite this, Karua proceeded to Uganda to defend opposition leader Kizza Besigye, who is also charged with treason
Upon arriving in Uganda, the People’s Liberation Party leader took to her X account to express relief at entering the country without any problems
Senior counsel Martha Karua has arrived in the Ugandan court to defend opposition leader Kizza Besigye.
On Wednesday, May 21, Karua joined the legal team representing Kizza Besigye, the four-time presidential candidate.
She was joined by human rights activist Lynn Ngugi, who was detained alongside her at Julius Nyerere International Airport in Dar es Salaam on Sunday, May 18, before they were both deported to Kenya.

What is Kizza Besigye charged with?.text: The Uganda's opposition leader appeared at Nakawa Magistrates Court accompanied by his aide Obeid Lutale and Uganda People’s Defence Forces Captain Denis Oola.
The 68-year-old Besigye risks the death penalty if convicted, since treason is a capital offence in Uganda.

Why is Kizza Besigye charged with treaso.text: The prosecution claimed that from 2023 to 2024, Besigye and his co-accused conspired to violently overthrow the Ugandan government.
State prosecutors alleged that Besigye, Lutale, and Oola held meetings in Geneva, Athens, Nairobi, and Kampala to plan and secure military and financial backing for their plot.
Court proceedings revealed that the suspects attempted to recruit and train Ugandans in Kenya for armed operations.
The three also face an alternative charge of misprision of treason for allegedly failing to report the plot to authorities.

The court was informed that investigations were ongoing, and because treason carries the death penalty, the matter was to be heard only in the High Court. Consequently, the accused did not enter a plea.

Besigye’s attorney, Erias Lukwago, requested his transfer to a specialised medical facility due to worsening health, but Magistrate Esther Nyadoi said she lacked jurisdiction to grant the request and that the case must first be referred to the High Court.
The accused were then remanded to Luzira Prison under tight security.
